question: What is YOGA?
answer: The word Yoga originated from the Sanskrit word “Yuj” which means ”Union” . Yoga is the path of achieving the union or balance of Mind, Body and Soul. It is a systematic process of achieving complete Well being at all levels – Physical, Mental, Emotional and Spiritual.

question: What is the difference between doing Yoga and doing physical exercises at a Gym. Is anyone better than the other?
answer: There are certain basic differences between the two : While exercise focuses mostly on the Body, Yoga focuses equally on the Mind, Body and Soul. Exercises usually entail fast, forceful and repetitive actions whilst Yoga is all about a conscious process of stretching, bending and maintaining steadiness which has multiple benefits. Exercising builds Strength and Stamina while Yoga improves Flexibility , develops Muscle tone, enhances Peace of mind and holistic well being. Both these have their own benefits and hence knowing the above differences as well as understanding your individual long term requirements is the key to choose what you need to do.

question: There are so many different types of Yoga nowadays. Which type of Yoga do you follow / practice / teach at SYVK?
answer: Yes…there are many different types of Yoga which are in vogue and hence it is indeed a challenge to understand and choose a particular style for oneself. We at SYVK follow the original path of Ashtanga Yoga founded by Maharishi Patanjali who collated the various practices of Yoga into the famous Patanjali Yoga Sutras. This philosophical handbook prescribes an 8-limbed path of Yoga consisting of Yamas ( Restraints ), Niyamas ( Observances ), Asanas ( Postures ), Pranayama ( Breath control ), Pratyahara ( Senses withdrawal ), Dharana ( Concentration ), Dhyana ( Meditation ) and Samadhi ( Self realization ).

question: What is the main difference between Basic Yoga and Power Yoga. Do you offer both of these at SYVK?
answer: Basic Yoga is a steady and energetic form of Yoga that helps stimulate the core parts of your body. It will physically and mentally challenge you to connect with your Inner Self and at the same time Healing, Detoxifying and Balancing your Body, Breath and Mind. Power Yoga is a dynamic flow of Asanas ( postures ) combined with powerful breathing exercises which mainly focusses on Body and Breath. It aims to build strength and endurance and this helps in burning calories too. At SYVK we offer both Basic as well as Power Yoga depending upon your requirements and suitability for the same.

question: Do I need to have a flexible body if I have to do Yoga?
answer: Being flexible is NOT a prerequisite for doing Yoga BUT your body becoming flexible is one of the surest benefits of doing Yoga!! We at SYVK believe in developing your flexibility at your own pace. What is important is that you be at it and do not give up. Our qualified and experienced Yoga teachers will always be there to assist and to propose modifications to the postures which you may find difficult, initially.

question: Will Yoga help me in reducing my body weight?
answer: Practice of Yoga regularly and correctly has a whole lot of physical and mental benefits. While Yoga definitely helps to develop muscle tone and increase the rate of metabolism, there are certain intense styles/postures which can burn your calories too!! But for successful weight loss, a balanced diet and a healthy lifestyle is very essential. You could also take up Advanced yoga or Power yoga to meet your weight loss requirement.

question: Are there any food / diet restrictions to be followed while doing Yoga?
answer: As per Ayurveda and Yogic literature, a Satvik diet is what is always prescribed for those who want to practice Yoga and enjoy its benefits. A Satvik diet usually includes foods and eating habits that are pure, essential, natural, energy providing, clean and fresh. It could also exemplify Ahimsa, non-violence, to Self as well as other living things and this is the reason why Yogis often follow a Vegetarian diet. A Satvik diet could include seasonal fruits, ripe vegetables, dairy products, nuts, seeds, oils, legumes, whole grains etc. Canned, cold, stale, refrigerated, preserved, impure, fermented foods and drinks etc. which are Tamasik in nature, are best avoided completely. Rajasik foods like coffee, tea, tobacco, green chillies, pepper, high quality wines etc. are also not favoured by Yogis.

question: What is the best time in the day to do Yoga?
answer: The best time in the day to do Yoga is first thing in the morning before breakfast. Upon waking, empty your bowels, bathe if you wish and commence your daily regimen of Yoga. As per Vedic tradition, Brahma Muhurta, which is about 1 hour and 36 minutes before sunrise and lasting up to 48 minutes after sunrise is the perfect time for Yoga. The second best time would be evening around the time of sunset. If both these timings are not suitable then Yoga can be practised at any convenient time of the day, but on an empty stomach. It does not even matter if Yoga is practised at different times on different days as long as it fits into a routine which is regular and sustainable.

question: Can I eat or consume water before doing Yoga?
answer: It is always advisable to do Yoga on an empty stomach. It is very important that the food in the stomach must be properly digested, else it will lead to uncomfortable situations during the twisting and turning, forward and backward bending postures in Yoga. Hence Yoga should be done with a gap of atleast 3 to 4 hours after a heavy meal and about 1 to 2 hours after breakfast / light meal / snacks. If you feel like eating something after doing Yoga, you should wait for at least 30 minutes as the body needs to cool down and attain normal metabolism levels. As far as drinking water is concerned, you can drink water at least 30 minutes before Yoga but ensure to empty your bladder before starting the practice. You may have a sip or two of water during the Yoga practice if really necessary.
